title: Low-Dose Oral Minoxidil: Is This the Secret to Long, Healthy Hair?

content: These days, the influence of social media trends can dictate cultural norms. Oftentimes, I have patients come in asking about the latest treatment trends they heard about on the internet and social media.

One quick search can bring up a ton of information -- some useful, some confusing. Before the short-lived hiatus of beloved TikTok, a quick search of “hair loss” pulled up many influencers discussing their experiences with minoxidil -- the good, the bad, and the hairy. It made me wonder. If I only had one treatment to offer for hair loss, what would I choose?

If you ask my medical assistants, my go-to hair loss treatment, hands down, is low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM). This medication is helpful for many types of hair loss and offers real and sustainable results. Statistically, there is a high likelihood of experiencing hair thinning, with the risk increasing with age.

By age 50, half of White men will experience hair thinning and 40% of women, with the risk increasing to 80% by age 70. The incidence of hair thinning is less in other ethnicities but may be underreported due to a lack of inclusion in studies. Additionally, patterns of hair loss can vary among ethnicities, with Black people more likely to have a preserved hairline and thinning at the crown versus White people who are more likely to have hairline thinning included.

sections.heading: Minoxidil Origins
content: In the early 70s, oral minoxidil was FDA-approved for the treatment of severe hypertension. It functions as a potent vasodilator, relaxing the smooth muscle within the vessels and allowing for improved blood flow. During treatment, many people noticed fuller scalp hair and increased hair growth on their bodies (hypertrichosis). Due to this unexpected side effect, topical minoxidil came to the market in the late ‘80s and was a popular hair growth solution for both men and women.

While an effective option for hair maintenance and prevention, topical application can be cumbersome, messy, and irritating. People wanted more aesthetically pleasing options for hair growth, which led to the rise of prescribing LDOM. This has been prescribed for both men and women.

sections.heading: Dosing
content: LDOM dosing can range between 0.625 milligrams to 5 milligrams. Typical dosing includes 0.625 milligrams to 2.5 milligrams for women and 2.5 milligrams to 5 milligrams for men.
Conditions Treated

Topical minoxidil is FDA-approved to treat androgenetic alopecia in men and women. In recent years, the off-label use of LDOM has gained popularity in its ease of use and efficacy. Minoxidil can also be an effective option for other hair conditions, including alopecia areata, scarring alopecia, and permanent chemotherapy-induced alopecia.

content: Additionally, LDOM also has some mild anti-androgen effects. One study showed a 0.22-fold decrease in 5-alpha reductase activity.
Topical vs. Oral Minoxidil

Ever wondered if there is any difference between oral vs. topical minoxidil? Well according to a recent study, the benefits are similar between the two. The study compared the use of 5 milligrams of oral minoxidil once daily to 5% topical minoxidil twice daily in 90 men with androgenetic alopecia. Over the four months studied, there was no difference in hair growth in the two groups. The most common side effects for people using oral minoxidil were headaches and increased face and body hair growth or hypertrichosis.
Does Topical Minoxidil Work for Everyone?

No. Minoxidil requires conversion to its active form, minoxidil sulfate. The enzyme known as minoxidil sulfotransferase is responsible for this conversion. The enzyme activity is hard to predict from person to person and typically requires a failed trial of topical minoxidil for 6 months. Topical minoxidil can be compounded with products like tretinoin, which can increase the expression of follicular sulfotransferase.

content: Oral minoxidil is a good option for those who used topical minoxidil for 6 months with no success. LDOM requires a lower amount of follicular minoxidil sulfotransferase activity when compared to topical minoxidil.
If You Use Minoxidil, Should You Use It Consistently?

Yes. The benefits of the medications are only seen with constant application. This is due to minoxidil’s short half-life of 4 hours. At the molecular level, minoxidil helps to shift hairs into the growing phase, increase the growth phase (thick, longer hair!), and increase hair follicle size. Medication is needed to maintain these shifts and once discontinued, the effects of the medications are reversed. This results in a “shedding” that returns the hair to pre-minoxidil condition. On average, it can take up to three months for the reverse to take effect.

sections.heading: What Are the Side Effects?
content: It is important to note that while there are many benefits of minoxidil use, there are potential side effects. Some reported side effects include
bullets: Hypertrichosis (increased face and body hair growth)

content_blocks.text: It is important to note that while there are many benefits of minoxidil use, there are potential side effects. Some reported side effects include
associated_bullets: Hypertrichosis (increased face and body hair growth)

content: In several studies, hypertrichosis is the most common side effect reported, occurring in 15% of people taking low-dose oral minoxidil. Despite this, it was almost never a reason to stop taking it. In some cases, grooming changes like dermaplaning or shaving were used. People taking higher doses, like 5 milligrams, were more likely to experience hypertrichosis.

Potential heart problems are also rare and present a minor concern. One study found no difference in blood pressure when compared to oral vs. topical minoxidil users. Lower leg swelling was found in 3% of patients and dizziness was reported in 2%.

Excessive fluid buildup around the heart was also a very rare side effect, although it has been reported in doses as low as 0.25 milligrams. Some related symptoms include progressive swelling of the face and body, shortness of breath, and difficulty breathing while lying flat. This is considered a drug reaction, which would require immediately stopping this therapy. Despite the seriousness of the side effect, it is extremely rare and the odds of developing this side effect are low.

content: Additionally, when you are starting minoxidil in any form, you may experience an initial shedding. Also referred to as “dread shed,” this is due to speeding up the shedding phase of your hair, also known as the telogen phase. This can occur as early as two weeks and can last up to eight weeks after beginning treatment. It has been reported that up to 24% of people using minoxidil have experienced new-onset shedding.
Does Overlapping Topical and Oral Minoxidil Stop “Dread Shed”?

Not according to a recent study. The study was split between people who were already on topical minoxidil and those who weren’t on topical therapy before starting LDOM. There was no difference in the two groups experiencing dread shed. Of note, the group using topical minoxidil was largely composed of women. The total shedding reports in the study was 5%.

content: LDOM is a great option if you are looking to slow down the almost inevitable effects of hair thinning. Like any treatment, consistency is key in achieving and maintaining results, as it can take between 6-12 months to show improvement. As always, I recommend a trip to your local board-certified dermatologist to discuss your specific healthy hair goals!
